{"comments": {"id": 11800, "count": 234, "talk_id": 1404}, "threadId": 11800, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "1404", "description": "Imagine a set of electronics as easy to play with as Legos. TED Fellow Ayah Bdeir introduces littleBits, a set of simple, interchangeable blocks that make programming as simple and important a part of creativity as snapping blocks together.", "event": "TED2012", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Ayah Bdeir: Building blocks that blink, beep and teach", "slug": "ayah_bdeir_building_blocks_that_blink_beep_and_teach", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "1267", "slug": "ayah_bdeir", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Ayah", "lastname": "Bdeir", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Engineer and artist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/a416d379f0a3e24d528262b18bcf45cceca19321_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Ayah Bdeir is an engineer and artist, and is the founder of littleBits and karaj, an experimental art, architecture and technology lab in Beirut.", "whylisten": "
Ayah Bdeir is the creator of littleBits, an open source system of preassembled, modular circuits that snap together with magnets – making learning about electronics fun, easy and creative. An engineer, inventor and interactive artist, Ayah received her master’s degree from the MIT Media Lab and undergraduate degrees in computer engineering and sociology from the American University of Beirut. Ayah has taught graduate classes at NYU and Parsons and taught numerous workshops to get non-engineers – particularly young girls – interested in science and technology. She is also the founder of karaj, Beirut’s lab for experimental art, architecture and technology. littleBits was named Best of Toyfair, has won the editor’s Choice award from MAKE magazine, and has been acquired by MoMA for its collection.

"https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/a416d379f0a3e24d528262b18bcf45cceca19321_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "", "whotheyare": "Ayah Bdeir is an engineer and artist, and is the founder of littleBits and karaj, an experimental art, architecture and technology lab in Beirut.", "whylisten": "
Ayah Bdeir is the creator of littleBits, an open source system of preassembled, modular circuits that snap together with magnets – making learning about electronics fun, easy and creative. An engineer, inventor and interactive artist, Ayah received her master’s degree from the MIT Media Lab and undergraduate degrees in computer engineering and sociology from the American University of Beirut. Ayah has taught graduate classes at NYU and Parsons and taught numerous workshops to get non-engineers – particularly young girls – interested in science and technology. She is also the founder of karaj, Beirut’s lab for experimental art, architecture and technology. littleBits was named Best of Toyfair, has won the editor’s Choice award from MAKE magazine, and has been acquired by MoMA for its collection.
"}], "speaker_name": "Ayah Bdeir", "tags": ["TED Fellows", "creativity", "education", "technology", "toy", "code"], "title": "Building blocks that blink, beep and teach", "video_type": {"id": "1", "name": "TED Stage Talk"}, "viewed_count": 1234667}]}
author: Ayah_Bdeir;
title: Building blocks that blink, beep and teach

aws-transcripts.transcript: This may sound strange, but I'm a big fan of the concrete block. The first concrete blocks were manufactured in 18 68. It was a very simple idea. Modules made of cement, of a fixed measurement that fit together very quickly. Concrete blocks became the most use construction unit in the world. They enabled us to build things that were larger than us buildings, bridges, one brick at a time. Essentially concrete blocks had become the building block of our time. Almost 100 years later, in 1947 Lego came out with this. It was called the automatic binding brick, and in a few short years, Lego bricks took place in every household. It's estimated that over 400,000,000 bricks have been produced or 75 bricks for every person on the planet. You didn't have to be an engineer to make beautiful houses, beautiful bridges, beautiful buildings, Lego make it accessible. No go ahead, essentially taken the concrete block the building block of the world and made it into the building block of our imagination. Meanwhile, the exact same year at Bell Labs the next revolution was about to be announced. The next building block the transistor was a small plastic unit that would take us from a world of static bricks piled on top of each other to a world where everything was interactive. Like the concrete block. The transistor allows you to build a much larger, more complex circuits, one brick at a time. But there's a main difference. The transistor was only for experts. I personally don't accept this, that the building block of our time is reserved for experts, So I decided to change that. Eight years ago, when I was in the media lab, I started exploring this idea of how to put the power of engineers in the hands of artists and designers. I am. A few years ago, I started developing a little bit. Let me show you how they work. Little bits are electronic modules with each one specific function. They're pre engineered to be light sound motors and sensors, and the best part about it is they snap together with magnets so you can't put them the wrong way. The bricks are color coded. Green is output. Blue is power thinkers input and oranges wire. So all you need to do is snap a blue to green and very quickly you can start major making larger circuits. You put a blue to green, you can make a light, you can put a knob in between. And now you've made a little dimmer Switch out the dimmer, the knob for a pulse module, which is here and now. You've made a little blinker at this brother for some extra punch and you've created a noise machine. I'm gonna stop so beyond. Beyond simple play, little bit are actually pretty powerful. Instead of having to program tow wire to start a little bit, allow you to program using very simple, intuitive gestures. So to make this blink faster, slower, you would just turn this knob and basically make it fall faster, Slower? The idea behind little bits is that it's a growing library. We want to make every single interaction in the world into ready use. Brake lights, sounds, solar panels, motors. Everything should be accessible. We've been giving little bits to kids and seeing them play with them, and it's been an incredible experience. The nicest thing is how they start to understand the electronics around them from every day that they don't learn at schools for example, how a nightlight works or why an elevator door stays open, or how an iPod response to touch We've also been taking little bit. It's to design school. So, for example, we've had designers with no experience with electronics whatsoever start to play with little bit as a material. Here you see with felt and paper water bottles we have Jordy making thief. A few weeks ago we took little bits Thio Rizzi and give them to some designers with no experience and injuring whatsoever just cardboard, wood and paper and told to make something. Here's an example of product. They made a motion activated confetti cannon ball. But wait, this is actually my favorite project. It's a lobster made a Flatow that's afraid of the dark. To these non engineers, little bits became another material. Electronics became just another material, and we want to make this material accessible to everyone. So little bit is open source. You could go on the website, download all the design files, make them yourself. We want to encourage a world of creators off inventors off contributors because this world that we live in this interactive world is ours. So go ahead and start inventing. Thank you
